headline: Prince Harry: Six key moments from BBC News interview - BBC News
context: Watch: Prince Harry's exclusive interview in full

annotations.paragraph: The Duke of Sussex has spoken exclusively to the BBC about his prospects of returning to the UK, relationship with his family and anger at losing his right to automatic full security protection when visiting from the US.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces the main topics discussed in the interview, which are directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: He made the comments after losing his latest legal challenge against the government over his security - a decision which he says has left him vulnerable to threats on his life.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the legal challenge and its impact on Prince Harry, which is relevant to the interview's content.

annotations.paragraph: Here are six key moments from his interview with the BBC's Nada Tawfik in California.
annotations.reason: This paragraph sets up the structure of the article by indicating that key moments from the interview will be highlighted.

annotations.paragraph: Any prospect of a return to the UK for Prince Harry, Meghan and their children - Archie, five, and Lilibet, three - is "impossible" in light of the Court of Appeal ruling, the royal told the BBC.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a specific quote from Prince Harry about his family's situation, which is a key moment from the interview.

annotations.paragraph: Prince Harry, who relocated to the US in 2020, said he "can't see a world in which I would be bringing my wife and children back to the UK at this point".
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from Prince Harry about his decision not to return to the UK, which is relevant to the interview's content.

annotations.paragraph: "The things that they're going to miss is, well, everything," he continued.
annotations.reason: This quote lacks context and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: He told the BBC: "I love my country, I always have done, despite what some people in that country have done...
annotations.reason: This quote provides insight into Prince Harry's feelings about his country, relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: "So I miss the UK, I miss parts of the UK, of course I do - and I think that it's really quite sad that I won't be able to show my children my homeland."
annotations.reason: This quote reveals Prince Harry's personal sentiments about missing the UK, relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: Prince Harry said there had been "so many disagreements" in the family, but the "only thing that's left" is the row over his security - which he said had "always been the sticking point".
annotations.reason: This provides specific information about family disagreements and security issues, relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: "There is no point in continuing to fight anymore, life is precious," he added.
annotations.reason: This quote is vague and does not add substantial information to the interview's key moments.

annotations.paragraph: Prince Harry also touched on the health of King Charles. The 76-year-old is undergoing treatment for cancer.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides new information about King Charles' health, which is relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: The prince said: "I don't know how much longer my father has - he won't speak to me because of this security stuff but it would be nice to reconcile."
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from Prince Harry about his relationship with his father, which is relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: He added "some members of my family will never forgive me" for writing his memoir Spare, and went on to say: "It would be nice to have that reconciliation part now.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into family dynamics and Prince Harry's feelings, which are relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: "If they don't want that, that's entirely up to them."
annotations.reason: This quote adds to the narrative of family reconciliation discussed in the interview.

annotations.paragraph: Prince Harry claimed that the downgrading of his security arrangements in 2020 was used as "leverage" over him after his decision to step down from front line royal duties and move to the US.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about Prince Harry's security concerns, which is relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: He said the court's decision this week, which said the way his security was removed was lawful, had "set a new precedent that security can be used to control", and would "imprison other members of the family from being able to choose a different life".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific commentary on the court's decision and its implications, which is relevant to the interview's key moments.

annotations.paragraph: Prince Harry said he had only been to the UK for funerals or court hearings since 2020, plus some charity engagements, claiming that he only receives full protection if he is visiting on official business.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers new information about Prince Harry's visits to the UK and his security arrangements, which is relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: "I can only come to the UK safely if I'm invited... there is a lot of control and ability in my father's hands," he added.
annotations.reason: This quote provides insight into Prince Harry's perspective on his security and relationship with his father, relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: Asked if he wanted the King to take steps to guarantee his security, he said: "I've never asked him to intervene - I've asked him to step out of the way and let the experts do their job."
annotations.reason: This paragraph reveals Prince Harry's stance on his father's involvement in his security, which is relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: He suggested the withdrawal of security had been an attempt to prevent him and Meghan leaving the royal fold, saying: "This, at the heart of it, is a family dispute."
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the security issue as a family dispute, which is relevant to the interview's key moments.

annotations.paragraph: "And it makes me really, really sad that we're sitting here today, five years later, where a decision that was made most likely, in fact I know, to keep us under the roof."
annotations.reason: This quote provides insight into Prince Harry's feelings about past decisions affecting his life.

annotations.paragraph: The prince said that, regardless of whether he is carrying out royal duties, the security risks he face remain the same - and have gotten worse in recent years.
annotations.reason: This statement addresses the ongoing security concerns faced by Prince Harry.

annotations.paragraph: Prince Harry said: "My status hasn't changed. It can't change. I am who I am.
annotations.reason: This quote highlights Prince Harry's perspective on his unchanging status.

annotations.paragraph: "I am part of what I'm part of, and I can never escape that. My circumstances will always be the same."
annotations.reason: This quote emphasizes Prince Harry's view on his inescapable circumstances.

annotations.paragraph: Harry also said: "I've given 35 years of service to this country, two tours of Afghanistan."
annotations.reason: This statement provides context on Prince Harry's service and dedication.

annotations.paragraph: "I was born into these risks, they've only increased over time."
annotations.reason: This quote provides insight into Prince Harry's perspective on his security risks.

annotations.paragraph: Prince Harry railed against the committee responsible for keeping senior royals safe, the Protection of Royalty and Public Figures (Ravec).
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces Prince Harry's criticism of the security committee, which is relevant to the interview's key moments.

annotations.paragraph: Ravec, which takes decision on behalf of the government, decided the prince would not automatically receive comprehensive security when in the UK as he stepped back from royal duties in 2020.
annotations.reason: This provides context on the security decision affecting Prince Harry, relevant to the interview.

annotations.paragraph: The committee's then-chair Sir Richard Mottram made that decision without carrying out a full review into threats Prince Harry faced at the time - but the Court of Appeal concluded he had done so for "sensible" reasons, and that a review would not have changed the outcome.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers important context about the decision-making process regarding Prince Harry's security.

annotations.paragraph: Prince Harry said his "jaw hit the floor" when he learned a representative of the Royal Household sits on the Ravec committee, and claimed that allowed it to exercise influence over what security members of the Royal Family get.
annotations.reason: This provides a significant revelation from Prince Harry about the influence on security decisions.

annotations.paragraph: Prince Harry claimed Sir Richard "abandoned" a full review of his security arrangements after speaking to the Royal Household.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a specific claim made by Prince Harry regarding his security arrangements.

annotations.paragraph: The prince also said: "I have had it described to me, once people knew about the facts, that this is a good old fashioned establishment stitch up - and that's what it feels like."
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from Prince Harry expressing his feelings about the situation.

annotations.paragraph: Prince Harry confirmed he would not be taking his legal challenge against the government to the Supreme Court, the only option left to him after Friday's ruling.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a significant update on Prince Harry's legal actions.

annotations.paragraph: He said the decision had "proven that there was no way to win this through the courts", adding: "I don't want any battles to continue.
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes Prince Harry's reasoning for not pursuing further legal action.

annotations.paragraph: "There is way too much suffering and way too much conflict in the world."
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a general statement not directly related to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: However, he did call on the government to directly intervene in how decisions are made by Ravec, which he said was "not constrained by law".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides new information about Prince Harry's call for government intervention.

annotations.paragraph: He said: "I'd ask the prime minister to step in. I would ask Yvette Cooper, the Home Secretary, to look at this very, very carefully.
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from Prince Harry, adding depth to his request for government intervention.

annotations.paragraph: "And I would ask her to review Ravec and its members... because if it is an expert body, then what is the royal household's role there if it isn't to influence and decide what they want for the members of their household?"
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides further context and a direct quote about Prince Harry's concerns regarding Ravec.

annotations.paragraph: Commenting after the BBC interview, Buckingham Palace said: "All of these issues have been examined repeatedly and meticulously by the courts, with the same conclusion reached on each occasion."
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a response from Buckingham Palace, contributing to the narrative.
